SummaryOfEvents:
During route navigation from Ronne to Copenhagen with 240 passengers and 32 crewmembers a fire arose in the engine room. The ships was four nautical miles south of Drogden light. 

The fire was efficiently exstinguished with an fixed high pressure water mist system. After the ship had been made ready, the ship continued its voyage towards Copenhagen by its own engine power.

The cause of fire was a leakage on a fuel oil reurn pipe on a main engine from where emitting oil had been ignited by the hot surface of the motor's exhaust system.

Location: About 2 cables S. of Newhaven east pier
English channel, about 20 miles from Falmouth
SummaryOfEvents: On 1 February 2002, the Maltese, 6395gt cargo ship Kodima was passage from Sweden to Libya. Between 19:00 hours and 19:50 hours her deck cargo shifted to port causing a list of 15° and, although course was altered towards Falmouth Bay, England, the list, compounding by  the  ship rolling in heavy seas, continued to increase. By 04:50 hours the following morning it has reached 40°, and the ship’s main engine and generators had become inoperable. With the ship stopped in the water about 20 miles from Falmouth, and drifting to the north-east, the master and crew were evacuated by helicopter. Attempt to secure a towline were unsuccessful, and Kodima eventually grounded on Tregantle Beach, Whitsands Bay at 18:55.

SummaryOfEvents: During towing of a split barge together with another Danish towboat in the Elbe in strong oncomming current, the ship capsized as they were turning a little to port in order to get over to another side of the river. The master and the officer fell into the water and when the ship had come aligned, the master was still at the ship but the officer had got away from the ship. The engine was still running, and the master managed to rescue the officer.

Location: 40 nm S.W. of St. Ann's Head, Bristol Channel
Indian Ocean, 1,400 nm N.E. of Madagascar
Black Sea, 80 miles from Sinop, Turkey
SummaryOfEvents: On 4.12.2001 at 01.00 M/V CHERNOMORETS letf the port of Sinop (Turkey, Black Sea), for destination, the port of Theodosia (Crimea, Black Sea) she was loaded with 297 mt of citric goods. In accordance with the Classification Certificate her deadweight equals 90t. Hence the vessel was overloaded. She had 21 crewmembers onboard. Due to the overload, and influence of stormy weather the vessel lost her stability, listed and sunk. The ship EPIRB had not been located in his prescribed place, but had been hidden in the chart room, therefore a distress signal was not sent. It happened on 04.12.2001 at 21.30 by the Ukrainian time in position 80 miles N of the port of Sinop. As a result, 6 people (including the master) are counted as missing assumed lost.

Location: 7 miles E. of Alnmouth, Northumberland coast

SummaryOfEvents:
The MV ELIXIR sailed from Vittoria, Brazil for Pohang, South Korea, on 15 November 2001 loaded with 40,388 mt of steel products.
The vessel was manned by 23 crewmembers of Greek, Filipino, Romanian and Ukrainian nationalities.
On 13 December 2001, at 0000 the vessel was passing through the Sundra Strait on a heading of 900.
The master was on the bridge during the passage through the strait but at 0125, when there were no ships around his vessel, he went down to his cabin to have a rest. He informed the second officer who was on watch, to call him if he needed him or when the vessel arrived at the Outer Channel.
The second officer was on watch together with a helmsman, who was hand steering the vessel. An able seaman was on look out.
Some time later the AB was requested to proceed to the forward deck for the anti-piracy patrol, leaving the second officer and the helmsman on the bridge.

At 0140, the second officer observed an approaching vessel, 10 miles away. At this time, he could see the red and green navigation lights of the approaching vessel.
When the vessels were about 5 miles apart, the second officer plotted the CPA 0.1 to 0.2 miles. By now only the green light of the oncoming vessel was visible.
He then checked the distance by the Variable Range Marker (VRM) and obtained a distance of 4.1 miles.
At this time the second officer contacted the other vessel by VHF on channel 16 and suggested to change over to channel 6. The officers on both vessels agreed to pass each other port-to-port.
The second officer instructed the helmsman to alter the course 100 to starboard to give more space for the approaching vessel.
The second officer could not see the red navigation light of the oncoming vessel at this time.
According to the CPA on the ARPA, the vessels were going to pass too close to each other in the port-to-port situation.
In view of this the second officer again contacted the other vessel by VHF and also flashed the Aldis lamp at the other vessel to ensure identification of his vessel.
When the distance showed 2.8 miles, the second officer realised that he cannot alter his course more to his starboard, because his ship was heading at P.P. Tidung. He also decided that if he slowed down his vessel, he still would not be able to pass clear of the oncoming vessel.
Therefore, he contacted again the other vessel, which turned out to be the MT SELE PERTAMINA 3006 on channel 16 and advised to pass port-to-port.
The officer on board the MT SELE PERTAMINA 3006 replied that it was ‘OK’ and confirmed to pass port-to-port. At this time the red navigation light of the MT SELE PERTAMINA 3006 was still not visible from the MV ELIXIR.
When at 0.7 miles away the second officer again tried to warn the other vessel by VHF and shouted ‘port to port’. At this time the MT SELE PERTAMINA 3006 started to alter her course to port, turning towards the MV ELIXIR. 
The second officer instructed the helmsman to go hard to starboard.
At 0205, in position 050 51.9’ S, 1060 29.9’ E, the vessels collided. The bow of the MT SELE PERTAMINA 3006 made contact with the MV ELIXIR on the port side in line with No.1 hold.
On feeling the collision, the master came up on the bridge and stopped the main engine. He saw the bow of the MT SELE PERTAMINA 3006 close to the aft port side of his vessel.
And ordered hard to port to the helmsman to avoid a second contact.
The master decided to drop anchor and assess the damage to his vessel.
The forepeak ballast tank, the No.1 hold and the No.1 double bottom ballast tank were flooded giving the vessel a heavy trim by the bow.
The MT SELE PERTAMINA 3006 sustained damages to the bulbous bow and forepeak ballast tank.

Location: Black Sea, off Sinop, 40 miles from the Strait of Istanbul's entrance
Vicinity of Fehmarn Belt Island, Germany.
SummaryOfEvents:
The MV STANISLAW KULCZYNSKI sailed from Asnaes, Denmark at 13:25 hours on 09 December 2001.
She was in ballast with draughts 4.3 m Fwd and 5.97 m Aft and was manned by 20 Polish crewmembers.
The intended destination was Ventspils, Latvia via the Great Belt.
At 20:00 hours on 09 December 2001, the third officer took over the watch from the chief officer.
The ship was making 14 knots on a true course of 1230 (T).
The distance to route “H” and Route “T ” junction buoy T-63 was 3.6 Nm. The master was on the bridge at this time. As it was good visibility, he decided to send the able seaman who was on lookout duty, down and stayed with the third officer on the bridge.

Both radars were on and the third officer was plotting and monitoring the ships in the area around his ship.
Ahead of his ship there was another ship making about 14.5 knots 10-150 on the starboard bow.
Two other ships were crossing the MV STANISLAW KULCZYNSKI’S course from port to starboard side, at 0.7 Nm and 0.9 Nm respectively.
At 20:10 hours, the ship crossing on the bow of the MV STANISLAW KULCZYNSKI crossed safely at a distance of 0.3 Nm and proceeded to starboard.
The other ship, 300 on the port bow of the MV STANISLAW KULCZYNSKI, which was now about 1.0 Nm away, changed her course to port.
On this new heading the ships were on a collision course, which was confirmed by the ARPA.
This alarmed the third officer who in turn notified his master.
The master instructed the third officer to sound the ship’s whistle in an attempt to warn the oncoming ship and turned his vessel’s wheel hard to starboard. After some time, when the master realised that a collision was inevitable, he turned the wheel hard to port in an effort to minimise the impact of the collision.
At 20:13 hours in position 540 36.1’ N, 0110 08.0’ E the ships collided, with the oncoming vessel which was the Antigua registered MV ATINA, hitting the MV STANISLAW KULCZYNSKI on the port side close to the engine room bulkhead and hold No.5.
The MV ATINA sustained damages to the port bow above the waterline while the MV STANISLAW KULCZYNSKI sustained damages to the shell plating and engine room bulkhead, also above the waterline. 
The MV STANISLAW KULCZYNSKI proceeded to a shipyard to effect repairs.
The MV ATINA continued on her voyage via the Kiel Canal.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

Location: 5 kms S.W. of Susami, Wakayama Prefecture
Approx. 20 nm E. of Skyros Island, Greece

SummaryOfEvents: The Danish fishing vessel KLAZINA VERA and the Estonian ro/ro containership KUNDA had a collision in Langelandsbaelt at buoy No. 5 in route H. KLAZINA VERA was proceeding on a southerly course in the Great Belt to the Baltic Sea. KUNDA was proceeding on a northerly course heading for Aarhus. The other vessel was observed in relatively proper time on both vessels. Recordings from the VTS Great Belt showed that KLAZINA VERA was proceeding in that side of the route, where the northbound vessels normally are proceeding. Approx. 3 minutes before the collision, KUNDA began to turn to starboard. At approx. the same time KLAZINA VERA began to turn to port. At the collision KLAZINA VERA was hit by the stem of KUNDA in the starboard side aft. KLAZINA VERA heeled over and sank shortly after the collision. The skipper and a fisherman managed to get out of the sinking vessel. They stayed at the stem, which was still over the water, until they were rescued by the pilot boat from Spodsbjerg. One fisherman was lost.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
The MV CAPTAGIANNIS loaded 27,286 mt of sulphur from the port of Kavkaz, Russia.
The ship was manned by 21 Greek, Egyptian and Ghanaian crewmembers.
The MV CAPTAGIANNIS sailed from Kavkaz on 07 November 2001, bound for the port of Sfax, Tunisia.
On sailing from Kavkaz, the vessel’s draught was 10.06 m on even keel and had 198 mt of F.O. and 27mt of G.O.
On the 11 and 12 November 2001, while on passage to Sfax, the ship encountered gale force weather from the South South East and she was rolling and pitching heavily, with water coming over the deck and the hatch covers.
The master altered the course from the intended 2530 to 2200 at position 340 45’ N, 0180 16’ E, to ease the ship’s movements and to try to avoid the bad weather as much as possible.
On 12 November 2001, at 2330, the charts in use on the bridge were changed, that is from B.A. chart No. 176 to B.A. chart No. 3403, which is the approach chart to Sfax.
On 13 November 2001, at 2340, the MV CAPTAGIANNIS ran aground in position 330 26.8’ N, 0110 23.25’ E.
The double bottom tanks were sounded and it was confirmed that there were no penetrations of the hull.
Tugboats were despatched to the scene of the grounding to assist the ship in the re-floating operation.
On 29 November 2001, the ship was re-floated and allowed to proceed under her own power to the port of Sfax, where the cargo was discharged.
After inspection by divers, it was found out that the ship had sustained minor indentations to the hull shell plating and she proceeded to Piraeus, Greece for repairs.
No pollution or injuries resulted from this grounding

SummaryOfEvents: Fire broke out in No. 1 engine.  This was extinguished, but later re-ignited.  The fuel valve on No. 1 engine could not be closed due to intense heat and the engine room was evacuated.  The quick closing fuel valve was shut and the vessel lost power.  Following extinguishing of the fire the engine room was re-entered and power restored.

Location: S.-W. lane of Dover Strait TSS, S.-E. of Hastings
Port of Big Creek, Stann Creek District
SummaryOfEvents:
The live-aboard dive boat WAVE DANCER sailed from Radisson Fort George at 17.30 on 6th October 2001 with 20 passengers and 9 crew on board for a one week diving holiday.  At noon on that day, "IRIS" tropical storm was located about 275 miles ESE of Kingston, Jamaica moving West-Northwest at 20 mph with maximum winds of 65 mph.  
Hurricane IRIS began to hit the port of Big Creek at about 19.30 hrs on 8th October 2001.  It was described by the National Weather Service in Miami as "an extremely dangerous Category 4 Hurricane".  The point of landfall of the center of the eye was between the town of Monkey River and the southern tip of Placencia.  Big Creek is within that range.
The WAVE DANCER broke away from its moorings at about 20.30hrs.  There was a collision between the stern of the WAVE DANCER and the bow of the BELIZE AGGRESSOR III at about the time the WAVE DANCER broke away from the dock.  The WAVE DANCER drifted, grounded and capsized resulting in the loss of 20 lives, those of 17 passengers and 3 crew.
ShipType1: passenger vessel converted into a live-aboard diveboat
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately 2054, while proceeding downbound under Bridge 11 in the Welland Canal, at Allanburg, Ontario, the bulk carrier WINDOC was struck by the bridge's vertical-lift span, which was lowered before the vessel had passed clear of the bridge structure.   The vessel's wheelhouse and funnel were destroyed. The vessel drifted downstream, caught fire, and grounded approximately 800 metres from the bridge.  Although the vessel's cargo of wheat was not damaged, the vessel was declared a constructive total loss.  The bridge sustained structural damage, and the Welland Canal was closed to vessel traffic for two days.  
There were no serious injuries or oil pollution.

SummaryOfEvents: On the morning of Friday 27 July 2001 the ship “Sea Swallow” left French port in Belmullet, Co. Mayo with both the skipper and his son onboard. They were carrying approximately fifty fully-grown shorn ewes to Inishkea North Island for summer pasture. They departed Frenchport at 11:20 hours approximately.  The weather was good, the sea was slight with south-westerly winds of 1 knot; it was cloudy and good visibility of 13 miles. The boat appears to have sunk while passing Duffur rocks at about 12:00 hours. The skipper was rescue but his son has not been recovered.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The Liberian flag passenger vessel NORDIC EMPRESS suffered a fire in her engine room to her number 3 engine at 22:36 LT on June 15, 2001, as she was sailing from Bermuda to New York to complete her seven day cruise.
The casualty resulted in no deaths or injuries to passengers or crew members, and there was no pollution.
With the help of a local tug, the vessel was able to return under her own power to Bermuda for repairs.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 24 May 2001 at 1906, the MV OLYMPUS left the port of Necochea, Argentina loaded with a cargo of 26,250 mt of bulk wheat.
The vessel was bound for San Francisco Do Sul, Brazil. The draught at the time of departure was Fwd. 9.95 m, Aft 9.98m.
On 27 May 2001 at 0800, the third officer took over the navigating watch accompanied by an AB, acting as a lookout. The weather was clear at the time, with visibility of about 4 miles.
At 0800, when the third officer took over the watch, the radars were switched off, as it was already daylight and clear weather. The culture on board was to keep the radar sets off in daylight and good visibility during navigation.
At around 0820 the visibility started to deteriorate suddenly due to a fog bank. The third officer switched on the radar sets and left them to warm up for a few minutes. (The radars normally needed 3 to 5 minutes to warm up)

The vessel’s speed at the time was about 10 knots with 114 revolutions per minute on the shaft.
The third officer switched on the automatic foghorn and went to the radar to try and fine tune the sets.
At this time, the third officer became aware of a vessel coming from the starboard side that was about 0.6 nautical miles away.
He instructed the AB to change over to hand steering and put the wheel hard to port.
Before the MV OLYMPUS started to react to the helm input, the other vessel, the MV SAO SEBASTIAO collided with the bow of the MV OLYMPUS.
After the impact the MV SAO SEBASTIAO almost lost all headway, while the MV OLYMPUS carried on. As a reaction to the impact the MV OLYMPUS rolled heavily to port and by the time she rolled back to starboard the bow of the MV SAO SDEBASTIAO was already abeam her accommodation and she was struck again just forward of the starboard lifeboat, causing damage to the starboard life boat, davits and some railings.
The master of the MV OLYMPUS, who was with the chief officer in the officer’s mess having breakfast and discussing the day’s work program, went up to the bridge and took over command.
Due to the damages sustained in the bow area and paint locker of the MV OLYMPUS, the forecastle caught fire and the chief officer and some crewmembers started to fight the fire, and managed to bring it under control about 90 minutes later.
The collision caused considerable damage to the MV OLYMPUS. The forecastle on the starboard side was heavily damaged and the side shell plating between the forecastle and part of the No. 1 hold was breached by the bow of the MV SAO SEBASTIAO. 
The hatch covers of the No.1 hold were displaced from the hatch coaming and also damaged.
When the vessels made the second contact the starboard lifeboat, davits and lengths of railings of the MV OLYMPUS were damaged. 
During the fire fighting the master assessed the damage sustained by his ship and decided to steer the ship inshore to shallower waters. The master was concerned that should the bulkhead between No.1 and No. 2 hold fail, the vessel would loose her reserve buoyancy and founder.
In this respect he steered to shallower waters with the intention of beaching the vessel if the need arises.
At position 300 30.2’ S, 0500 16.5’ W, the master dropped anchor in 13 metres of water.
The owners contracted a salvage company to salvage the vessel and after the necessary arrangements were made, the ship’s cargo was lightered on to another vessel.
The MV OLYMPUS was later on towed to the San Francisco Do Sul inner anchorage were she arrived on 15 June 2001.
The MV SAO SEBASTIAO sustained minimal damage to the stem with one hole above the waterline on its port bow and the loss of both anchors.

On 20 May 2001 at 13:50 hours, it was notified that a smouldering fire in the wood cargo “CIC Vision” in hold.
The fire was later extinguished with assistance from the US Coast Guard.

During the morning of 18 May 2001, a Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MVA) surveyor reported to the MAIB that the ro-ro ferry P&OSL  Canterbury, had suffered flooding of her forward machinery space while entering Dover Harbour the  previous day. The MAIB began an investigation immediately.

At 13:18 eastern daylight time on 14 May 2001, in clear and calm weather, while outbound and fully laden, the Canadian Transfer struck bottom approximately 1.25 nautical miles west of the Goderich Harbour outer piers. Substancial damage was sustained by the ship.

SummaryOfEvents: While on passage from Bilbao, Spain to Avonmouth, UK, between 25 and 26 April 2001 the 2999gt Netherlands-registered ship Dutch Navigator encountered poor weather conditions. This resulted in a shift of nine of her cargo containers units in the foremost bay of her hold, Bay 1. The incident was reported to the MAIB, via the DTLR’s Duty Officer, by the Secretary of State’s Representative for Salvage and Intervention (SOSREP) at 03:50 hours on 28 April. An investigation began at 04:30 that day.

SummaryOfEvents: At about 15:00 hours on 18 April 2001, the factory trawler freezer Fame suffered a major failure in the factory freezer equipment that resulted in the release of the entire charge of refrigerant into the engine room. The refrigerant quickly displaced in the engine room, which caused the total loss of main and auxiliary power. With a 3° to 4° starboard list, the ship remained increased; the list became 8° to 10°. Inspection of the fish processing tween-deck showed an accumulation of seawater on the starboard side and the starboard list increased to 28° to 30°. The decision was made to abandon the ship. On 19 April at about 08:45 hours, 21 crewmembers abandoned the ship into two liferafts, while the remaining three crewmembers were taken off the ship by the fast rescue craft from a nearby fishing ship. The Fame   subsequently downflooded and sank stern first

SummaryOfEvents:
The Sofie Theresa on voyage from Rotterdam to Rouen, a fire occurred on 13 March 2001 in engine room, caused by a hydraulic oil leakage, spraying hydraulic oil into the room. Oil was ignited by hot surfaces on generator set.

Fire was extinguished by crew. No persons injured

SummaryOfEvents:
The Kristal was on voyage from Mormugao, India to Amsterdam; Netherlands, loaded with 28,500 of molasses. On 25 February whilst heading to Cape St Vincent, the Kristal encountered heavy weather, the condition of weather worsened further as the ship entered the Bay of Biscay.

On 27 February 2001, at 12:25 hours the crew noticed that the Kristal had suffered a complete structural failure and had broken in two, in way of nos. 4 COTs, approximately between frames 114 and 124.

The crew members abandoned the ship safely but in the process of being rescued, the port lifeboat capsized and out of a crew complement of 35, only 24 survived. Seven days later, nine crew members were still missing. 

On 02 March the forward section of the Kristal was blown up by explosives and sunk at the explosives dumping area Fosa de Hercules. On 06 March 2001, about 100 miles north west of La Coruna, Spain, the aft section, whilst under tow in bad weather, listed heavily and sank in about 4,900 metres of water

SummaryOfEvents:
At 1450 LT (UTC+9H), 3 February 2001, SHIN NICHIYO MARU left Yokkaichi Port in Mie Prefecture for Hakata Port in Fukuoka Prefecture via Kanmon Channel.
When SHIN NICHIYO MARU was proceeding to the entry of Hakata Port, it ran aground in position, 305 degrees 350 meters from Kurinokamisho Beacon at 0604 LT (UTC+9H), 5 February .

Weather: Cloudy Wind: East-3 Tide: The end term of the flood tide Visibility: Good

SHIN NICHIYO MARU sustained holes in the starboard side and bottom plates and the sea water flooded in the cargo holds, and sank at 0650 LT near the grounding position.
All crew members moved into its life raft before sinking and were rescued by a patrol ship.

Location: 70 miles E.-S.E. of Halifax, Nova Scotia

SummaryOfEvents:
On February 13 at 0630 NICOLAI MAERSK arrived at Ferguson Container Terminal in Auckland and berthed starboard side to. Before arrival a port side lifeboat drill was scheduled to take place immediate following the arrival and under the command of the chief officer.

At 0715 the lifeboat was ready for launching. 7 crew members were on board the lifeboat and were fastened in their seatbelt. The boat was lowered to a position level with the boat deck, and at that point the hoisting function was tested. The winch motor did not hoist and the drill was therefore abandoned and an attempt was made to hoist the boat by hand. In order to investigate the cause the electrician was sent down to the HI-press room, where the electrical panel board of the davit motor is located. By pushing different contacts at the panel board the winch motor could be brought to hoist in jerks.

Suddenly the winch started to hoist steady and fast and continued hoisting after the davits had reached their uppermost position. Due to the continued pull the wires broke and the boat fell 16 metres down to the sea. One of the crew members was so seriously injured, that he died shortly after, 3 other crew members were seriously injured and the remaining 3 crew members sustained light to moderate injuries.

The investigations following the accident has shown, that by pushing the contacts at the panel board the Proximity Cut-off Switches at the davits, which cut off the current for the winch motor just before the davits reaches their stop position, and the Over Current Control Relay, which cut off the current for the winch motor in case of overload, were bypassed.

SummaryOfEvents: On 26.01.2001 at 00.00 M/V "Pamiat Merkuriya" left the port of Istanbul for destination, the port of Eupatoria (Crimea, Black Sea), and was loaded with 324 mt of general cargo (instead of allowed 200 mt) including 235 mt on deck (instead of allowed 25 mt). Thus the vessel was overloaded. It had 27 crewmembers and 25 passengers onboard. The route should have been used in accordance with the GMDSS area A.1 (no more then 25 miles offshore) but the master kept route area A.2 (100 miles from offshore). Due to the overload, free spaces into the ship's tanks and loss of stability M/V "Pamyat Merkuria" listed and sunk. It happened on 26.01.2001 at 18.52 by the Ukrainian time in position 43°47'O N 31°43'0 E. As a result, 8 persons were lost and 12 persons counted as missing assumed lost.
